releases/0/tender/title: DELIVERING AGRICULTURAL GREENHOUSE GAS AND AMMONIA INVENTORIES AND PROJECTION
releases/0/tender/description:
As part of the UK government's commitments under the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change and the UK Climate Change Act, the Authority produces an annual inventory of agricultural greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions. Similar obligations exist for the production of an annual inventory of ammonia emissions under the UNECE Convention on Long-Range Transboundary Air Pollution. This project will help the Authority meet these obligations. Estimates of agricultural emissions are prepared for the Authority and shared with BEIS as part of the overall emissions reporting for the whole UK economy. Contractor(s) will work closely with the Authority, BEIS, Ricardo Energy & Environment, and the UK's Inventory Agency to ensure delivery of the Project.

 This project will deliver the annual inventories of ammonia and GHGs to the Authority on a timely basis as detailed in Section 4 of this specification. The project will also deliver annually updates projections of emissions. The project will compile the GHG using the UKs country specific agricultural inventory model approach developed under the GHG R&D Platform. Emissions estimates will be generated using the inventory calculations model developed under project SCF0102. Annual estimates of ammonia emissions will be produced from the same model. Details of the model are available from the authority on request.

Additional information: 
Please note that Defra procurement uses e-tendering, provided by Bravosolutions. In order to access the Bravo system you will need to be registered.
Could I therefore request that you register on the Bravo portal for Defra.
If you're already registered on the Bravo portal please check that your registration includes Defra, as you have to specify us in order to correctly receive the tender documents.
If you have any problems with the registration process, please contact the Bravo helpline on 0800 368 4850 or alternatively email them at help@bravosolution.co.uk. The link you require for new registration/amendments to registrations is -
https://defra.bravosolution.co.uk

releases/0/tender/title: Quality Improvement Support
releases/0/tender/description:
BSMHFT is seeking a strategic partner to develop and implement a large scale change programme acrossthe organisation. The programme will implement and establish the principles of QI methodology. The strategicpartner will have a proven track record in developing sustained cultures of continuous QI in healthcare withdemonstrable outcomes.
Translating QI into healthcare carries greater complexity than perhaps any other service or productionenvironment. The range of services provided, facilities, people involved and patient and clinical needvariability all combine to impact on the opportunity for waste and interrupted flows. This is exacerbated by thegeographical spread of our services.
With patient safety paramount, the need to provide any change programme within a clinically safe and effectiveenvironment is essential. QI methods are expected to not only reduce waste and flow variability but to alsoimprove quality as errors and unnecessary variance are removed and time/resources are made available toprovide safer, better services. It is essential that stakeholders clearly understand that this programme is aboutQI rather than being financially-driven, though we expect to identify opportunities for productivity and efficiencyopportunities as a by-product.
We have a number of improvement ambitions, which we would expect the programme to help us deliver in thelong term:
â¢ Move our CQC rating from Requires Improvement to Outstanding
â¢ Fully empowered and engaged workforce
â¢ Devolved decision making and accountability
â¢ Teams as the building block for everything rather than professions and functions
â¢ Alignment of strategic change initiatives
â¢ Sustainable productivity and efficiency opportunities
â¢ Slick and aligned management and governance processes
The programme will:
â¢ Undertake an assessment of QI readiness
â¢ Develop and embed QI techniques and processes into BSMHFT
â¢ Include executive, senior staff, team leaders and par

releases/0/tender/title: Robotic Immunoassay System
releases/0/tender/description:
The Health & Safety's Laboratory (HSL) is inviting tenders for the supply of a Robotic Immunoassay System. 

HSE's allergen monitoring service currently uses a 8 year old Tecan Evo system, with fixed pipetting probes.  This is used primarily to measure by immunoassay low levels of allergens that have been extracted from filters after air sampling. The automated immunassay system is also used in the development of immunoassays. Overall the automation has a medium workload, and would be in use on a daily basis. 

We are looking to replace the current Tecan Evo instrument.  We are looking for a system that can be used by staff who do not have considerable technical knowledge of the equipment and programming software, and will allow us to reduce maintenance expenditure in the future. We understand that the use of dispoable pipettes will incurr increased consumable exposure, but we have some methods where the ability to ensure zero carry-over between samples is necessary.

Additional information: The Contract Start and Award dates are estimated & may be subject to change.

If you are interested in this opportunity you will be required to register on HSE's eProcurement portal.   
 
You will need to follow this link https://in-tendhost.co.uk/hse/aspx/Home  where you can register free of charge.
 
HSE publishes all its opportunity's on this portal and you may on occasion be notified about these.
  
Any queries regarding this opportunity are to be submitted via the HSE e-Procurement portal.  Any changes or additional information, including any answers to queries will be published on the portal.

The maximum budget available for this requirement is Â£90,000 including VAT, offers over this amount will not be accepted.

releases/0/tender/title: Northamptonshire County Council - Services for the Treatment of Drug and Alcohol Addictions
releases/0/tender/description:
Northamptonshire County Council is running a simultaneous procurement process for Services for the Treatment of Drug and Alcohol Addictions. The detailed requirements are defined in the Specification, but please see below summary for each Lot.

LOT 1: Structured Treatment Service for adults and young people in Northamptonshire will include prescribing, OST, psychosocial interventions and responsibility for the management of the residential rehab, inpatient and ambulatory detox, shared care with GP surgeries, needle exchange, supervised consumption with pharmacies, the distribution of naloxone and foil. It will also introduce an integral mental health service capable of meeting the needs of Northamptonshire clients; provide structured treatment for young people allowing them access to the specialist resources as needed and house the re-designed single point of contact (SPOC) representing all services.
LOT 2: Recovery Service for all treatment and recovery clients in Northamptonshire will be peer based and provide an interface with structured treatment. It will host mutual treatment options and include the management of the PHaSE housing project. 
LOT 3: Specialised Training Service, providing training on drug and alcohol awareness for substance misuse services for older people aged 45 and over.
LOT 4: Young People's Early Intervention Service - Services for young people with or living with problematic substance misuse will be divided into two. Those who require structured treatment (those with moderate to severe addictions) will be managed in the community by the Early Intervention service (Lot 4) with structured treatment drawn down from the all-through service (see fig.1). This configuration takes account of best practice, ensures that those who need treatment can access the best available with the interventions taking place within the young person's community environment. The Early Intervention service will comprise the larger part and will have workers embedded in clusters (schools or Early Intervention) where they will devise an appropriate prevention agenda for young people. It will support local services in the earlier identification of young people, at risk of, or substance abusing. It will provide assessment of the severity of the problem and steer the young person towards less harmful behaviours. Where the young person requires a more intensive treatment the community based early intervention service will draw down the practitioner and resources from the treatment service (Lot 1).

The service will be required from 1st April 2018 for an initial period of 4 years (up to 31st March 2022) with Lots 1, 2 and 4 having an option to extend for a further period of up to 4 years. The Authority believes that TUPE does apply to all Lots at its commencement. The deadline for completed ITTs to be received on the LGSS eTendering Portal (www.lgssprocurementportal.co.uk) is 12:00noon on Friday 3rd November 2017.

releases/0/tender/title: EHRC 1718-77 Monitoring of key sectors performance against the Public Sector Equality Duty
releases/0/tender/description:
The Commission now seeks to engage the services of a suitably qualified provider to gather and analyse evidence of the work undertaken across key sectors to meet the requirements of the PSED legislation.  
This project aims to:

â¢	Gather evidence from all listed bodies on their work in specific areas to comply with the general duty.
â¢	Provide good practice examples of the work undertaken by each organisation
â¢	Highlight where the most impact has been achieved - where real outcomes have improved people's lives
â¢	Draw together conclusions on progress within the sectors on the specific areas
â¢	Provide recommendations on how further progress can be achieved.

The monitoring will specifically focus on the following areas:
â¢	Local Authorities - action taken to address identity based bullying in schools.
â¢	Health Boards/Trusts - access to mental health services by people from different protected characteristics
â¢	Universities - action taken to tackle identity based violence, as well as work to tackle the gender, disability and ethnicity pay gaps
â¢	Further Education Colleges - how colleges are promoting diversity within apprenticeship schemes
â¢	Fire and Rescue Services - workforce diversity and access to information
â¢	Welsh Government - increasing diversity of public appointments  
â¢	Other listed bodies including Assembly Sponsored Public Bodies - work in relation to the recruitment and employment of disabled people and procurement
 Please register the Commission's procurement portal for the full tender pack: https://procontract.due-north.com/Register

releases/0/planning/documents/0/descript: Early engagement notice on Contracts Finder
releases/0/tender/title: Consultancy Services: Business Case for a Potential Kew University
releases/0/tender/description:
Science has always been the heart of RBG Kew's purpose. Our collections, our people and our partnerships enable us to make an invaluable and highly relevant contribution to some of the biggest issues facing the global population. We do this through research, conservation, training and inspiring others about the importance of plant and fungal science.

We have existing partnerships to deliver an MSc programme, diplomas and short courses. We recognise however that we may be able to optimise even further our offer in line with the current scientific research mission, and as a result RBG Kew's Executive Board wish to explore the opportunity to create a "Kew University". 

We are considering seeking professional assistance to produce a Full Business Case from which the Executive Board of RBG Kew can take a decision, in principle, about whether to proceed with the concept of a Kew University.

To this end we will be carrying out a soft market testing exercise, the aims of which include but are not limited to: 

â¢             Testing the clarity of our stated requirements;
â¢             Establishing if the market has experience of being involved in delivering similar projects; and
â¢             Ascertaining if there is an appetite within the market to tender for the delivery of these services

We are looking to test this proposition with Consultancies who have worked extensively in the Higher Education Sector, has the demonstrable experience, and is qualified to deliver a project of this complexity.  

If you would be interested in participating in this Soft Market Testing exercise you will be required to review our draft specification and respond to a short questionnaire.  We will also be hosting a Supplier Engagement Day on 10th July 2017.  

If you are interested in participating in the Soft Market Testing and/or attending the Supplier Engagement Day please complete the attached Non Disclosure Agreement and return by email to procurement@kew.org not later than 12 noon on 10th July 2017

releases/0/tender/title: Ground Investigation Survey Framework
releases/0/tender/description:
The following is a brief outline of the services to be provided by the Contractor including, but not be limited to the following:
Site Operations - i.e. the type of exploratory holes (boring, drilling, pits, trenches, etc). It shall also be stated whether sampling and in-situ testing are required.
Ancillary Works - i.e. if installations, post Site Operations monitoring and/or sampling are required.
Laboratory testing - i.e. if laboratory testing is required and whether it is geotechnical, chemical, etc.
Reporting - what reporting is required i.e. Field Report(s), Laboratory Testing Report(s), Ground Investigation Results Report, Ground Investigation Report (GIR).

A more detailed description is provided in the Works Specification.

releases/0/tender/title: Market Warming Exercise: Employment Support Pilot
releases/0/tender/description:
The WMCA is seeking to engage with the market place to seek specialist views and expertise on a Employment Support Pilot. With this in mind, WMCA intend to arrange a market warming event and would like interested parties to be involved to attend, learn more, and offer expert advice about how best to deliver this exciting opportunity. To express an interest in attending the market warming exercise, please complete the PQQ questionnaire. 

 Further key detail around expressing an interest in this Market Warming Exercise are listed below: 

 Portal Website: https://wmca.bravosolution.co.uk, 
 PIN Title: Employment Support Pilot - Market Warming Exercise-2017-042289, 
PIN LINK: http://ted.europa.eu/TED/notice/udl?uri=TED:NOTICE:518918-2017:TEXT:EN:HTML, 
 Bravo Solution Project Reference: Project_173 - Employment Support Pilot, 
 Bravo Solution Response Reference: pqq_85 - Expression of Interest to attend Employment Pilot Market Warming Exercise. 

Once registered on the portal please access Project_173 on our e-tendering portal and respond to PQQ_85 to express an interest in attending the market warming event. This is not a formal PQQ or expression of interest in a tender, it is to be used purely for suppliers to express interest in attending a West Midlands Combined Authority (WMCA) market warming exercise for the Employment Support Pilot. Please note that date of the market warning event will be 19th January 2018 and will be held at WMCA, 16 Summer Lane, Birmingham, B19 3SD. Should this event be over subscribed, WMCA will consider arranging a second event.

Additional information: Please review the above links to view further information about the forthcoming procurement opportunity. 

PLEASE NOTE THAT THIS NOTICE IS FOR EARLY ENGAGEMENT ONLY. Opportunities regarding the full tender exercise will be published at a later date.

releases/0/tender/title: Corporate Vehicle Body Repair Framework
releases/0/tender/description:
The Council is seeking to establish a Framework Agreement with suitable contractors with a local presence to provide a corporate vehicle body repair service, including the option of insurance repairs to both corporate vehicles and third party vehicles.

The purpose of the Framework is to appoint Contractors who will ensure that corporate and third party vehicle body repairs are carried out in a timely manner and conform to all current Health and Safety requirements and to minimise the cost of repair, transportation costs and waste.

The Framework will provide a fully comprehensive service for vehicle body repairs and a repair network across Dorset for a wide variety of vehicle types.

The users of the Framework will be Dorset County Council (including Dorset Highways Organisation (DHO) who will be the contracting party to the Framework Agreement, and Dorset Waste Partnership (DWP)) and Dorset Fire & Rescue Service (DF&RS)

The successful Contractors will be responsible for establishing a safe, effective and efficient bodywork repair network that provides the Council with a comprehensive service across the whole of Dorset. This may take the form of Contractors with an established sub-contractor base.

Additional information: The Framework Agreement is to be split between the following Lots:

Lot number / name	Vehicle Size	Supplier repair base required in:
1	Small/Medium vehicles (West)	Up to 7.5 tonnes	West Dorset 
2	Small/Medium vehicles (East)	Up to 7.5 tonnes	East Dorset 
3	Large vehicles (West)	7.5 tonnes and over	 West Dorset 
4	Large vehicles (East)	7.5 tonnes and over	 East Dorset 
5	Small/Medium/Large vehicles	All	North Dorset/Wiltshire for D&WF&RS 

Tenderers may tender for a single Lot, multiple Lots or all Lots. Only one (1) supplier will be awarded per Lot.

releases/0/tender/description:
Fenland District Council require a specialist printing supplier for the printing and posting of Garden Waste Bin Stickers, approx. 22,000 per annum currently.  

The successful supplier will also be required to provide a web portal for uploading of .CSV files along with logging the unique property reference number (UPRN).  The web portal should provide a full reporting facility to enable the council to see the status of orders such as printed, dispatched, cancelled and replacements all linked to the UPRN. 

Therefore suppliers with relevant experience of Wheelie Bin Subscription Stickers and Services are invited to tender.  Expressions of interest to receive tender documents to procurement@fenland.gov.uk

Tender return deadline Monday 9th October 2017.  (12 noon).

releases/0/tender/title: Archaeological Services
releases/0/tender/description:
Fenland District Council is seeking tenders for the provision of archaeological services in relation to delivering two projects âWisbech Big Digâ and âWisbech Undergroundâ.  The Wisbech Big Dig and Wisbech Underground form two of the projects set out in the Activity Statement for the Wisbech High Street Townscape Heritage project which is part funded by the Heritage Lottery Fund (HLF).

Wisbech Big Dig is to develop, support and deliver a number of community archaeology events in and around the High Street during the delivery phase of the project and will include a mixture of 'in ground' and building archaeology.

Wisbech Underground is to research, map and investigate the network of cellars, underground warehouses and tunnels including community and local school engagement. 

Experienced Companies/Organisations qualified to undertake archaeological services and community engagement projects should request tender documents from procurement@fenland.gov.uk

Additional information: Tender Return Date:  1pm, 15th December 2016
